Homage to Bodhisattva Stainless-Vow If any good sons or good women receive and uphold the names of these buddhas and bodhisattvas, they will transcend the world for thirty eons.

Homage to Buddha Sun-Disk-Light-Superior, homage to Bodhisattva Sun-Light If there are people who receive and uphold the names of this buddha and bodhisattva, they will transcend the world for a thousand eons.

Homage to Buddha Universal Jeweled Canopy If there are good sons who receive and uphold the name of this buddha, this person will transcend the world for four great eons, always be born in the presence of buddhas and bodhisattvas, and will no longer commit the five heinous crimes.

Homage to SamÄdhi-Superior-Resolute Buddha. If a good man receives and upholds the name of this Buddha, he will attain a thousand samÄdhis, transcend a thousand kalpas in the world, and have the same merit as Maitreya Bodhisattva.
Homage to RatnakusumagÄtra-prabhÄsa-Å›rÄ« Buddha. If there are people who receive and uphold the name of this Buddha, they will transcend incalculable kalpas in the world.
Homage to the Supreme-Saá¹ƒkusumita-abhyudgata-rÄja Buddha. If there are people who receive and uphold the name of this Buddha, they will transcend forty kalpas in the world.
Homage to the TathÄgata Ratnakusuma-vikrÄ«dita-rÄja Buddha. If good men receive and uphold the name of this Buddha, they will transcend innumerable kalpas in the world and always attain past lives.
Homage to the TathÄgata Ratnakusuma-vikrÄ«dita-rÄja Buddha. If there are people who receive and uphold the name of this Buddha, they will attain a thousand samÄdhis.
All sentient beings take refuge in such a person, and they are praised by all Buddhas and TathÄgatas. Such a person transcends the world for a thousand eons and will soon turn the Dharma wheel.
Homage to TathÄgata MahÄprabhÄ. If a good man receives and upholds the name of this Buddha, he will transcend the world for forty eons.
Homage to Buddha Ratnagarbha. If a good man receives and upholds the name of this Buddha, he will transcend the world for sixty eons.

Homage to Buddha RatnÄgrya. If a good man receives and upholds the name of this Buddha, and if there are people who give away the seven treasures equal to Mount Sumeru as offerings, as well as worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River,
if there are people who receive and uphold the name of this Buddha, their merit will surpass that.

Homage to the Venerable One who has realized the fundamental state, Homage to the Venerable One with the right aspiration, Homage to the Venerable One with right speech, Homage to the Venerable One with the great title, Homage to the Venerable One who is kind and virtuous, Homage to the Venerable One who is free from defilements, Homage to the Venerable One with the renowned name, Homage to the Venerable One who is truly good, Homage to the Venerable One who is complete, Homage to the Venerable One who is like an ox king Take refuge in these and other well-known great arhats.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Respectfully requesting the Buddhas of the ten directions, the scriptures of the twelve divisions, all sages and saints, the eight groups of spiritual beings, and the sentient beings of the Dharma realm, the great assembly present, to bear witness.
Disciples!
From beginningless time until now, we have created immeasurable and boundless offenses. Today, with utmost sincerity, we confess and repent, and take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha of Infinite Purity in the East, Homage to the Buddha of Mount Sumeru in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Accumulated Vajra Steps in the West, Homage to the Buddha of the Wise Supreme in the North, Homage to the Buddha of Greatly Increasing Light in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of Wonderful Treasures in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of the Single Vehicle in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of Destroying Mara's Net and Walking Alone in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of Fearless Intention in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of the King of Infinite Honored Ones Free from Defilement in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.
Disciples!
Now, for the sake of all sentient beings and for my own body, I take refuge and repent in the presence of the Buddhas of the ten directions.

All sentient beings, for immeasurable eons, do not recognize the Buddhas or the kindness of their parents, do not understand wholesome dharmas, and create various evils. Relying on their own lineage and various wealth and treasures, they indulge in licentiousness in their prime and commit evil deeds. Their minds think unwholesome thoughts and their mouths engage in evil actions, and they do not see their faults in the deeds they create according to their minds.

Foolish ordinary beings are ignorant and covered in darkness, they associate with evil friends and their minds are disturbed by afflictions. Due to the five desires, their minds give rise to anger and resentment, and they are insatiable and thus create various evils. They associate with non-sages and give rise to stinginess and jealousy.

Due to poverty, one engages in deceit and evil, is bound to others, is always fearful, and lacks self-mastery while committing evil deeds. Greed, anger, and delusion agitate one's mind, and one creates evil due to the torment of thirst and craving. Relying on clothing, food, and women, one is afflicted by the bonds and creates evil. One may have lustful thoughts towards other men, or be attached to the thought of women in cows, horses, donkeys, mules, sheep, and all kinds of birds and beasts. Not following the Buddha's teachings, one creates evil deeds.
The three karmas accumulated by body, speech, and mind - such numerous and boundless offenses are now all repented.
Disciples!ğŸ”½From beginningless time until today, we may have been disrespectful towards the Buddha, Dharma, and the noble Sangha. We now repent of all such offenses.
We may have been disrespectful towards pratyekabuddhas and bodhisattvas. We now repent of all such offenses.

Due to lack of wisdom, they slander the true Dharma, do not know to respect parents and elders, are covered by delusion and confusion, arrogant and indulgent, and due to greed, anger, and delusion, they create various evils. We now repent of all such offenses.

They enjoy drinking alcohol without knowing moderation, and may give alcohol to monks, to those who uphold the precepts, to bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, to those who have extinguished their minds, or to those in meditative concentration. Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. We now repent and take refuge with a sincere mind.
Disciples!

From beginningless kalpas until now, we have committed various evils, and due to these causes and conditions, we have experienced great sorrow and suffering, poverty and hardship, anxiety and fear, and have always been timid due to fear of evil karma. In all places, we have had no joy or happiness for a moment. The greatly compassionate World-Honored Ones in the present in the ten directions are able to remove all the fears of sentient beings. We pray that they accept our sincere repentance.

All past evils are now repented. Present actions are sincerely revealed. What has not been done will never be done again. What has been done will not be concealed. The three kinds of physical actions and the four kinds of verbal actions, the three kinds of mental actions, and the practices of karma, are now all repented. The difficulties of birth and death, the various desires, the difficulties of foolish afflictions, and so forth, are now all repented.

The difficulty of a restless mind, the difficulty of associating with bad friends, the difficulties of the three realms of existence, and the difficulties of the three poisons, encountering the difficulty of no difficulty, encountering the difficulty of a good time, cultivating merit and virtue, and encountering the Buddha are also difficult. All such difficulties are now repented.
Disciples!
From beginningless kalpas until now, we have killed all the Three Jewels, teachers, parents, six relatives, good friends, and sentient beings in the Dharma realm, whose number is unknowable;
Stealing from all the Three Jewels, teachers, monks, parents, six relations, relatives, good and virtuous friends, and sentient beings in the Dharma realm, the number is unknowable;

Giving rise to wrong thoughts towards all the Three Jewels, teachers, monks, parents, six relations, relatives, good and virtuous friends, and sentient beings in the Dharma realm, the number is unknowable.ğŸ”½Lying and deceiving all the Three Jewels, teachers, monks, parents, six relations, relatives, good and virtuous friends, and sentient beings in the Dharma realm, the number is unknowable;ğŸ”½Frivolous speech teasing all the Three Jewels, teachers, monks, parents, six relations, relatives, good and virtuous friends, and sentient beings in the Dharma realm, the number is unknowable;

Harsh words scolding, slandering, and disparaging all the Three Jewels, teachers, monks, parents, six relations, relatives, good and virtuous friends, and sentient beings in the Dharma realm, the number is unknowable;
Slandering and causing discord, destroying all the Three Jewels, teachers, parents, six relations, relatives, good friends, and sentient beings in the Dharma realm, the number of which is unknowable.

Or breaking the five precepts, eight precepts, ten precepts, ten wholesome precepts, two hundred and fifty precepts, five hundred precepts, the three categories of bodhisattva precepts, ten inexhaustible precepts, up to all precepts, and all precepts of deportment, etc.

Doing oneself, teaching others, rejoicing in seeing others do, the number of which is unknowable. Such various offenses are also like the boundless and innumerableå¾®å¡µ of the great earth in the ten directions.

The sins we have committed are also boundless and innumerable. The sky is boundless, and the sins we have committed are also boundless. The means are boundless, and the sins we have committed are also boundless. The nature of dharmas is boundless, and the sins we have committed are also boundless. The dharma realm is boundless, and the sins we have committed are also boundless. Sentient beings are boundless, and the plundering and killing we have done are also boundless. The Three Jewels are boundless, and the harm we have caused them is also boundless. The precepts are boundless, and the transgressions we have committed are also boundless.
Such sins, from the highest bodhisattvas down to the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, are unable to know them. Only the buddhas can know the extent of our sins.

Now, before the Three Jewels and all sentient beings in the dharma realm, we confess and repent, not daring to conceal them. We only pray that the Three Jewels in the ten directions and all sentient beings in the dharma realm will listen to our repentance.

May the disciples, by inheriting the merit generated from repenting like this, wish to forever abandon the womb in life after life, and go wherever their mind wishes, attaining the six spiritual powers to rescue and embrace all suffering beings. As long as the Dharma realm of space exists, my vows shall be like this.
May all beings in the hells, hungry ghosts, and all poor and suffering beings, as well as those tormented by afflictions and suffering, have all their suffering eliminated.

Moreover, may the disciples, by inheriting the merit accomplished from repenting like this, wish to depart from birth and death and reach the other shore of great wisdom, turn the unsurpassed wheel of subtle and pure Dharma, and accomplish and perfect all their vows and aspirations.

Moreover, may the blind see, the deaf hear, the mute speak, the naked be clothed, the poor and destitute obtain treasure troves, with granaries overflowing and nothing lacking, and may all receive peace and happiness, such that not a single person suffers.

Also, may sentient beings look at each other with a compassionate mind and the eyes of a Buddha, with an upright and dignified appearance that people delight in seeing, adorned with the most excellent form and appearance, becoming true good and virtuous spiritual friends for the sake of enlightenment.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Bodhisattva Who Attains the Lotus Treasure of the Retribution of Karma, Scroll 1. Baota previously entered the Hell of Stretching Flesh.
Why is it called the Hell of Stretching Flesh?
The hell is forty yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls and covered with an iron net above, with smoke and fire burning together, no different from above.
On the ground there are iron spikes, also burning with fire. In the middle there is an iron bed over five hundred steps in size, with fire burning on the bed, burning the sinners.
In the south gate there are six hundred sinners, resembling human forms but not human beings, one zhang tall, also without mouths, eyes, hands, feet, or the six sense organs.
At that time, the horse-headed rakshasa held an iron hook in his hand and hooked them from the back.
The bodies of the sinners moved as if they were human voices, crying out:
What sins have I committed to suffer such suffering?
The jailer struck the body and entered the prison. Iron spikes in the prison pierced the body, and blood flowed from the body into the fire.

There were also hungry ghosts that came to eat the flesh, hungry dogs that came to drink the blood, iron crows that came to peck at the tendons, and violent winds that blew on the sinners. In a single day and night, they suffered ten thousand hardships, dying a thousand times and being reborn a thousand times, dying ten thousand times and being reborn ten thousand times.
If they were reborn as humans, they were poor, ignorant, and did not recognize the Buddha's words.
Baota asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
What sins did these monks commit to suffer such suffering?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied:

These monks received the Buddha's precepts, but did not seek unsurpassed enlightenment. They only sought fame and profit in the present life. Because of their greed for drinking alcohol, they broke the Dharma and precepts, with thirty-six faults;
For this reason, he fell into this hell.
Hearing this, Baodai wept and left.
